filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; UNC LibrariesAugust 2022
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of sixteen impressions of plates for America a Prophecy not used in any copy of the poem, and a copperplate fragment.
These loose impressions form a new category of graphic works, referred to in the index of copies as "MPI," an abbreviation for Miscellaneous Plates and Impressions. As a group, MPIs reveal Blake's creative process as it unfolded through production, providing insights and new information about designs and texts. For example, Blake executed three plates that he rejected and did not use in any copy of America. They are designated Plates a, b, and c and are here displayed as Objects 6, 7, and 8. Plate a has the same text as Plate 5, with an added figure in flames holding a spear standing in the left margin. Plate b is a variant of Plate 6, with variants in design and text. Plate c is not a variant of any published plate and contains a unique text and designs. It may have been meant to be placed between Plates 10 and 11, or possibly after Plate b. Plate c includes complex pencil revisions by Blake. Plate d, another rejected plate, is already in the Archive under Separate Plates. It is known only because Blake used part of it to create “A Dream of Thiralatha,” which he included in the Large Book of Designs.
Songs Copy U was printed in orange ink, given orange frame lines and page numbers, and finished in watercolors and pen and ink. It was produced in the same style on the same Ruse & Turner paper as Songs Copy T, The Marriage of Heaven and Hell Copy G, The Book of Urizen Copy G, Visions of the Daughters of Albion Copies O, N, and P, The Book of Thel Copies N and O, and Milton Copy D. This set of illuminated books—which, with the exception of Visions Copy N, are in the Archive—was produced in 1818 and represents Blake’s return to illuminated printing. Except for a few copies of Songs and Milton between 1802 and 1811, Blake had not printed an illuminated book—or a group of them together—since 1795.
Object 17 shows a fragment of the copperplate of Plate a, which is the only surviving fragment of one of Blake’s copperplates etched in relief. The verso, Object 18, shows the head of a saint engraved by Thomas Butts, Jr., the son of Blake’s patron, who was studying engraving with Blake c. 1806-1808.
Ten of the fourteen lifetime extant copies of America were printed in 1793 on both sides of leaves in bluish and greenish black inks and left uncolored. Object 4, an impression of Plate 1 from the Rosenbach Museum, was printed with these copies, in bluish black ink, but it was finished in black and light sepia washes, the only impression among the America MPIs that was colored. Objects 9, 10, and 11, three impressions of Plate 4, were also printed among these first copies, when Blake masked the last five lines so that they would not print. Object 15 is an impression of Plate 15 that was presumably not used because it was too lightly printed in olive brown.
Object 16 is another impression of Plate 15, but in reddish brown ink, as are Objects 3 and 12, impressions of Plates 1 and 10. All three impressions in reddish brown are posthumous, printed by Frederick Tatham, who printed America Copy P, c. 1832, which is in the Archive, in this color.
America Copy MPI can be accessed like plates in copies of America and compared with impressions from the same copperplate using the "Objects from the Same Matrix" feature in the second navigation bar below the image. The Archive will gradually publish groups of miscellaneous plates and impressions for each illuminated book (some groups consisting of over forty impressions), which will enable users to trace the evolution of Blake's printed designs.
The Archive now contains fully searchable and scalable digital editions of 122 copies of Blake's nineteen illuminated books. Users may view color corrected digital images of Blake's works at their true size, and enlarge and rotate these images to examine texts and illustrations in detail. The images are accompanied by diplomatic transcriptions and editors' notes, as well as illustration descriptions that make it possible to search Blake's works for visual motifs. The Archive also provides full bibliographic and provenance information for each digital edition it publishes.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objdescid.origination: William Blake author, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer, colorist. Blake or his wife Catherine might have added the black and brown washes on Object 4, but this is far from certain. Blake may have added the pencil lines on Object 7. He added the pencil lines and annotations on Object 8.
Catherine Blake printer. William Blake's wife Catherine probably helped him print Objects 1-2, 4-11, and 13-15.
Frederick Tathamprinter. Objects 3, 12, and 16 were printed c. 1832 by Tatham.

Thomas Butts, Jr. delineator, etcher. The image on Object 18, the verso of the copperplate fragment from *America* Plate a, was executed by Thomas Butts, Jr., while he was a student of Blake's c. 1806-1808. Butts may have copied the image from the work of another artist.

provenance.name: Multiple
provenance.note: Object 1 (Bentley Plate 1): Probably inherited from Blake by his wife Catherine upon his death in 1827; probably acquired by Frederick Tatham upon Catherine Blake's death in 1831; acquired by George A. Smith and bound by him in "about 1853" (Bentley page 337) with other works by Blake, including the manuscript "Order" of the *Songs of Innocence and of Experience*; the volume offered, presumably by Smith, at a Puttick and Simpson auction, London, 3-4 July 1863, no lot number recorded (£15.15s., possibly bought-in by Smith given the reappearance of the volume in the Smith auction of 1880); the volume offered by the dealer Bernard Quaritch, 1864 *Catalogue of Books*, item 6521, possibly on consignment from, or in partnership with, Smith (£21); the volume sold by Smith, Christie's, 1 April 1880, lot 168 (£66 to Quaritch); the volume apparently lent by Quaritch to William Muir, who used some works as the basis for his facsimiles; the volume offered by Quaritch, Oct. 1883 *Catalogue of Works on the Fine Arts*, item 10,252 (£80), May 1885 catalogue, *William Blake's Original Drawings*, page 2, no item number (£80), and 1887 *General Catalogue of Books*, volume 2, item 10,252 (£80); the volume acquired by Bernard Buchanan Macgeorge between 1892 and 1906; the volume sold from the Macgeorge collection, Sotheby's, 1 July 1924, lot 133 (£345 to the dealer E. Parsons & Sons); the volume, possibly with some leaves removed, offered by Maggs Bros., 1924 catalogue 456, item 53 (£630); the volume acquired no later than 1927 by George C. Smith who disbound the volume; this print sold from George C. Smith's collection, Parke-Bernet, 2 Nov. 1938, lot 23, bound in a blue morocco volume with Objects 6-8, 11, 13-16 ($500 to the dealer A. S. W. Rosenbach acting for Lessing J. Rosenwald); given by Rosenwald to the Library of Congress in 1943.

Object 2 (Bentley Plate 1): Early history unknown; sold by the auction house Hodgson's c. 1913 to Geoffrey Keynes; bequeathed by Keynes to the Fitzwilliam Museum in 1982 and accessioned by the Fitzwilliam in 1985.

Object 3 (Bentley Plate 1): Frederick Tatham, who printed this impression, probably c. 1832; acquired at an unrecorded time by Philip Hofer; inherited in 1984 by his son, Myron Augustus Hofer; bequeathed by M. A. Hofer to the Houghton Library, Harvard University, in 1992.
Object 4 (Bentley Plate 1):Early history unknown; acquired at an unrecorded time by the dealer A. S. W. Rosenbach; given by Rosenbach to the Rosenbach Museum and Library and accession by it in 1954.

Object 5 (Bentley Plate 3): Early history unknown; acquired by J. (John?) Gibbs, perhaps c. 1850, and inserted by him or by Theodore Irwin as leaf 572 in vol. 2 of the extra-illustrated Kitto Bible; the Kitto Bible acquired by Henry E. Huntington in 1919; this impression removed from the volume at an unrecorded time prior to 1980 by the Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens.
Object 6 (Bentley Plate a): As for Object 1.
Object 7 (Bentley Plate b): As for Object 1.
Object 8 (Bentley Plate c): As for Object 1.

Object 9 (Bentley Plate 4): Acquired at an unknown time by Robert Arthington and sold from his collection, Sotheby's, 17 May 1866, lot 24, bound in calf with forty-eight drawings, etchings, and engravings by Blake,including this impression (£11 to "Pickering," probably the dealer B. M. Pickering); possibly William Fuller-Maitland until his death in 1876; the volume sold Christie's, 1 June 1887, lot 258 (£34 to Henry White); the volume sold from White's collection, Sotheby's, 22 April 1902, lot 270 (£87 to "Roberts," probably a dealer); the volume sold Sotheby's, 9 Dec. 1905, lot 921 (£80 to "Paul," probably a dealer); the volume sold Sotheby's, 15 Dec. 1906, lot 482 (£155 to the dealer "Abbey" acting for the Pierpont Morgan Library, now the Morgan Library and Museum); the leaves, including this impression, disbound and mounted by the Morgan Library and Museum.

Object 10 (Bentley Plate 4): Early history unknown; bound by a dealer or collector into an extra-illustrated copy of Mrs. A. E. Bray, *Life of Thomas Stothard, R.A.* (London: John Murray, 1851); acquired c. 1941 by Geoffrey Keynes and removed by him from the book; bequeathed by Keynes to the Fitzwilliam Museum in 1982 and accessioned by the Fitzwilliam in 1985.

Object 12 (Bentley Plate 10): Frederick Tatham, who printed this impression, probably c. 1832; acquired at an unrecorded time by W. E. Moss; sold from his collection, Sotheby's, 2 March 1937, lot 170 (£12 to "Morgan," either a code name for Geoffrey Keynes or an agent acting for him); bequeathed by Keynes to the Fitzwilliam Museum in 1982 and accessioned by the Fitzwilliam in 1985.
Object 16 (Bentley Plate 15): Frederick Tatham, who printed this impression, probably c. 1832; as for Object 1 beginning with George A. Smith c. 1853.

Object 17 (Bentley Plate a, copperplate fragment, recto): Cut by Blake from Plate a of *America* and given to Thomas Butts, Jr. (1788-1862), to whom Blake taught engraving beginning no later than 1806 and continuing until at least 1808; the verso (Object 18) used by Butts to engrave his own composition; sold the "Property of Descendants of Thomas Butts, jun.," Sotheby's, 22 March 1910, lot 446, included in a cabinet used by Butts for his engravings and engraving tools (£30.20s. to the dealer James Tregaskis, possibly acting for W. E. Moss); the copperplate removed from the cabinet and sold from the Moss collection, Sotheby's, 2 March 1937, lot 171 (£50 to the dealer A. S. W. Rosenbach, probably acting for Lessing J. Rosenwald); given by Rosenwald to the National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C., in 1943.
Object 18 (Bentley Plate a, copperplate fragment, verso): As for Object 17.

desc.objtitle: America a Prophecy, Object 1 (Bentley 1, Erdman i, Keynes i)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design embodies the destructiveness of warfare. In the middle distance is a stone wall with, on the right, the fragments of a top carved with classical motifs. A great gap appears to the left, and in this gap sits a giant winged figure. He is nude and muscular, with prominent knees and feet and both arms shackled and chained to the ground or to remnants of the wall on which he squats or sits. His legs are drawn up in an extremely contracted posture, with his knees to his shoulders. His head is lowered and rests on his knees; his face is not pictured. His hair is long and curly. The contracted posture and lowered head suggest despair. He may be Albion's Angel, the representative of the establishment forces, or Orc, the personification of revolution. To the right is a family group, all nude. A woman, very probably a mother, sits on a fragment of the stone wall, legs crossed. Her hair is long and her face expresses a brooding fear, despair, or simply exhaustion. Her mouth is closed and the edges of her lips are turned downwards. She holds in her lap a young child, probably male. He faces forward but perhaps looks up toward the woman. His right knee is prominent. Another child, of uncertain gender, leans against the woman's left thigh and hip and hides his or her head below the woman's left arm. This figure's legs are crossed at the ankles. We see this figure from behind. On the ground below the woman is the haft of a broken sword, and further to the left is a dismounted cannon. The sky is dominated by dark clouds, perhaps of smoke.

component.illusobjdesc: A giant winged male sits or squats in a gap in a partly-destroyed wall. He is nude and muscular, with prominent knees and feet and both arms shackled and chained to the ground or to the remnants of the wall on which he squats or sits. His legs are drawn up in an extremely contracted posture, with his knees to his shoulders. His head is lowered and rests on his knees; his face is not pictured. His hair is long and curly. The contracted posture and lowered head suggest despair. He may be Albion's Angel, the representative of the establishment forces, or Orc, the personification of revolution.
The giant winged figure is shackled and chained.

Three nude figures, probably a mother and two children, huddle together. The woman sits on a fragment of the stone wall. Her hair is long and her face expresses a brooding fear. Her mouth is closed and the edges of her lips are turned downwards. She holds in her lap a young child, probably male. He faces forward but perhaps looks up toward the woman. His right knee is prominent. Another child, of uncertain gender, leans against the woman's left thigh and hip and hides his or her head below the woman's left arm. We see the child from behind.

A nude female, probably the mother of the two children with her, sits on a fragment of the stone wall. Her hair is long and her face expresses a brooding fear, despair, or simply exhaustion. Her legs are crossed. Her mouth is closed and the edges of her lips are turned downwards. She may be frowning. Her right hand rests on her right knee. She holds in her lap a young child, probably male.
The woman holds in her lap a nude child, probably male. He faces forward and bends his head back. He may be looking up at the woman. We see only his face, right upper arm, and prominent right knee.

A nude child of uncertain gender huddles with the woman. We see this figure from behind; his or her head is hidden by the woman's left arm. The figure's legs are crossed at the ankles; the buttocks are prominent. Long hair cascades over the figure right shoulder.

The middle distance of the design is dominated by a stone wall, partly ruined. The top is decorated with classical motifs, perhaps including the egg and dart motif (upper right) and palmettes on the fragment of the wall on which the woman sits.
The sky is dominated by clouds, perhaps of smoke.
A dismounted cannon lies on the ground.
The fragment of the wall on which the giant winged figure sits looks like a plinth. This effect suggests that the figure is like a statue.
The haft of a broken sword lies on the ground below the woman.

objnote.p: The black and brown washes might have been added by Blake or his wife Catherine, but this is far from certain.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design embodies the destructiveness of warfare. In the middle distance is a stone wall with, on the right, the fragments of a top carved with classical motifs. A great gap appears to the left, and in this gap sits a giant winged figure. He is nude and muscular, with prominent knees and feet and both arms shackled and chained to the ground or to remnants of the wall on which he squats or sits. His legs are drawn up in an extremely contracted posture, with his knees to his shoulders. His head is lowered and rests on his knees; his face is not pictured. His hair is long and curly. The contracted posture and lowered head suggest despair. He may be Albion's Angel, the representative of the establishment forces, or Orc, the personification of revolution. To the right is a family group, all nude. A woman, very probably a mother, sits on a fragment of the stone wall, legs crossed. Her hair is long and her face expresses a brooding fear, despair, or simply exhaustion. Her mouth is closed and the edges of her lips are turned downwards. She holds in her lap a young child, probably male. He faces forward but perhaps looks up toward the woman. His right knee is prominent. Another child, of uncertain gender, leans against the woman's left thigh and hip and hides his or her head below the woman's left arm. This child's legs are crossed at the ankles. We see this figure from behind. On the ground below the woman is the haft of a broken sword, and further to the left is a dismounted cannon. The sky is dominated by dark clouds, perhaps of smoke.

component.illusobjdesc: A giant winged male sits or squats in a gap in a partly-destroyed wall. He is nude and muscular, with prominent knees and feet and both arms shackled and chained to the ground or to the remnants of the wall on which he squats or sits. His legs are drawn up in an extremely contracted posture, with his knees to his shoulders. His head is lowered and rests on his knees; his face is not pictured. His hair is long and curly. The contracted posture and lowered head suggest despair. He may be Albion's Angel, the representative of the establishment forces, or Orc, the personification of revolution.
The giant winged figure is shackled and chained.

Three nude figures, probably a mother and two children, huddle together. They match the color of the surrounding stones, and hence they look like statues. The woman sits on a fragment of the stone wall. Her hair is long and her face expresses a brooding fear. Her mouth is closed and the edges of her lips are turned downwards. She holds in her lap a young child, probably male. He faces forward but perhaps looks up toward the woman. His right knee is prominent. Another child, of uncertain gender, leans against the woman's left thigh and hip and hides his or her head below the woman's left arm. We see this figure from behind.

A nude female, probably the mother of the two children with her, sits on a fragment of the stone wall. Her hair is long and her face expresses a brooding fear, despair, or simply exhaustion. Her legs are crossed. Her mouth is closed and the edges of her lips are turned downwards. She may be frowning. Her right hand rests on her right knee. She holds in her lap a young child, probably male.
The woman holds in her lap a nude child, probably male. He faces forward and bends his head back. He may be looking up at the woman. We see only his face, right upper arm, and prominent right knee.

A nude child of uncertain gender huddles with the woman. We see this figure from behind; his or her head is hidden by the woman's left arm. The figure's legs are crossed at the ankles; the buttocks are prominent. Long hair cascades over the figure right shoulder.

The middle distance of the design is dominated by a stone wall, partly ruined. The top is decorated with classical motifs, perhaps including the egg and dart motif (upper right) and palmettes on the fragment of the wall on which the woman sits.
The sky is dominated by clouds, perhaps of smoke.
A dismounted cannon lies on the ground.
The fragment of the wall on which the giant winged figure sits looks like a plinth. This effect suggests that the figure is like a statue.
The haft of a broken sword lies on the ground below the woman.

objnote.p: In Copies C-I, K, L, and R, the word "Preludium" (not "PRELUDIUM," pace Bentley page 91 and Erdman page 802) is printed above this plate from a small, separate copperplate, Plate e, 2.4 x 8.0 cm. In Copies A, B, O, and this separate impression, the word "Preludium" is omitted. In Copy M, "PRELUDIUM" (all capitals) is written by hand.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains considerable text, it appears as though the plate is treated as a single design extending across the top one third, down the left margin, and across the lower margin. A large tree, perhaps an oak, with arching branches dominates the top left of the design. The vegetation right and left of the large trunk may be separate bushes. Below and to the right of its trunk is a large stone or an earthen bank (possibly with a few tufts of grass) to which is shacked a nude, youthful male by both hands and feet. His arms are spread out horizontally on the rock, as if crucified; his legs are also spread apart. His torso and neck are twisted, perhaps in pain; he faces up. His mouth is slightly open; he may be speaking or crying in pain. His hair is curly; he is probably Orc, the spirit of revolution here restrained. To the right are a nude male and female, both standing. The female, with legs spread apart, grasps her head with both hands, as if in mourning or despair. We do not see her face, but her upper torso is twisted to the left—toward the shackled youth. She may be Enitharmon, Orc's mother. Further to the right, the male stands with legs spread apart. His body faces us, but he turns his head to the left and may be looking at the shackled youth. His arms, with elbows bent, are raised over his head, with his hands raised, palms out, and the fingers of both hands spread apart. His hair is spiky or flame-like; his general expression is one of horror or grief. His mouth may be slightly open; he may be speaking or crying out in sorrow. This may be Los, Orc's father. Alternatively, the couple has been identified as Adam and Eve, or as the "Dark virgin" and Urthona (another name for Los) mentioned on this plate (lines 12, 2). The roots of the tree descend through the left margin, perhaps taking on anthropomorphic shapes. At the end of the roots, in the far lower left corner of the plate, sits or squats a nude, youthful male in a severely contracted posture. His legs are drawn up, with his head resting on his knees. He faces forward, with a grim expression, and holds his crossed hands over his ankles. His hair is curly or flame-like; his general expression is one of horror or grief. This may be another representation of Orc, as the personification of underground forces of revolution now enclosed but with the potential to break out. A reticulated worm, with six loops, fills the lower margin. The loops suggest (although they do not quite form) a spiral.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude, youthful male is shackled to a stone or an earthen bank by both hands and feet. We can see a link or two of chains attached to the shackles. His arms and fingers are spread out horizontally on the rock, as if crucified; his legs are also spread apart. His torso and neck are twisted, perhaps in pain; he faces up. His mouth is open; he may be speaking or crying in pain. His hair is curly; he is probably Orc, the spirit of revolution here restrained.
The wrists and ankles of the youth with arms and legs spread bear shackles and a few links of chains.

A nude female, with long hair and legs spread apart, grasps her head with both hands, as if in mourning or despair. We do not see her face, but her upper torso is twisted to the left—toward the shackled youth. She may be Enitharmon, Orc's mother, but she has also been identified as the "Dark virgin" named on the plate (line 12).

A nude male stands with legs spread apart. His body faces us, but his head is turned to the left and may be looking at the shackled youth. His arms, with elbows bent, are raised over his head, with his hands raised, palms out, and the fingers of both hands spread apart. His hair is spiky or flame-like; his general expression is one of horror or grief. His mouth is slightly open; he may be speaking or crying out in sorrow. This may be Los, Orc's father, but he has also been identified as Urthona (another name for Los, mentioned on this plate) and as Adam.

In the far lower left corner of the plate sits or squats a nude, youthful male in a severely contracted posture. His legs are drawn up, with his head resting on his knees. He faces forward, with a grim expression, and holds his crossed hands over his ankles. His hair is spiky or flame-like. This may be another representation of Orc, as the personification of underground forces of revolution now enclosed but with the potential to break out.
A large, reticulated worm fills the lower margin. Its six loops suggest, but do not quite form, a spiral.

A large tree, perhaps an oak, dominates the top left quarter of the plate. Its branches arch over to the right; a few leaves appear on the descending branches far right. Its roots descend down the left margin of the plate; some have anthropomorphic shapes, particularly left of lines 11-16 of the text.
The vegetation right and left of the large trunk of the tree may be separate, leafy plants.
The ground below the shackled figure may be covered with grass or perhaps moss.
The youthful male is shackled to a large stone or earthen bank.
Narrow shadows appear below the feet of the standing man and woman.
The contracted figure lower left sits on a mound.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The spaces between lines of text are filled with vegetative motifs, including vines. Some bear leaves, most prominently right of lines 17-18, and some may bear flowers. A vine to the right of line 6 forms a loop. The vine left of lines 20- 21 forms a small spiral.

component.illusobjdesc: The spaces between lines of text are filled with vegetative motifs, including vines. Some bear leaves, most prominently right of lines 16-17, and some may bear flowers. A vine to the right of line 6 forms a loop. The vine left of lines 20- 21 forms a small spiral.

l.note: In Copies C-I, K, L, and R, the word "Preludium" (not "PRELUDIUM," pace Bentley page 91 and Erdman page 802) is printed above this plate from a small, separate copperplate, Plate e, 2.4 x 8.0 cm. In Copies A, B, O, and this separate impression, the word "Preludium" is omitted. In Copy M, "PRELUDIUM" (all capitals) is written by hand.

lg.l: The shadowy daughter of Urthona stood before red Orc,
When fourteen suns had faintly journey'd o'er his dark abode;
His food she brought in iron baskets, his drink in cups of iron;
Crown'd with a helmet & dark hair the nameless female stood;
A quiver with its burning stores, a bow like that of night.
When pestilence is shot from heaven; no other arms she need:
Invulnerable tho' naked, save where clouds roll round her loins,
Their awful folds in the dark air; silent she stood as night;
For never from her iron tongue could voice or sound arise;
But dumb till that dread day when Orc assay'd his fierce embrace.The "c" in "embrace" at the end of line 10 is printed very lightly and is difficult to see.
Dark virgin; said the hairy youth. thy father stern abhorr'd;
Rivets my tenfold chains while still on high my spirit soars;
Sometimes an eagle screaming in the sky. sometimes a lion.
Stalking upon the mountains, & sometimes a whale I lash
The raging fathomless abyss, anon a serpent folding
Around the pillars of Urthona, and round thy dark limbs,
On the Canadian wilds I fold, feeble my spirit folds.
For chaind beneath I rend these caverns; when thou bringest food
I howl my joy: and my red eyes seek to behold thy face
In vain! these clouds roll to & fro, & hide thee from my sight.The "ght." in "sight." at the end of line 20 printed very lightly and are difficult to see.

desc.objtitle: , Object 6 (Bentley a, Erdman a, Keynes a)

objnote.p: This plate is a variant of Plate 5 printed from a different copperplate than the one bearing Plate 5. This variant plate does not appear in any copy of *America*. Object 7 (Plate b) is printed on the verso of this impression of Plate a.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The area above the text bearing the heading ("A / PROPHECY," lines 1-2) apparently represents the sky. Three birds fly on extended wings; one of these seems to be soaring upwards. Upper left, a nude, muscular male also seems to be ascending. He has apparently broken free of the chains that still dangle from his wrists. His left arm is at his side; his right arm is bent back over his right shoulder. His right leg is bent behind him out of view. His hair may be curly. He faces forward, with head tilted up. This may be another representation of Orc or, more generally, humanity freed from its chains by revolution. The words of the heading are integrated into vegetative design motifs, including several vines with leaves, spiraling vines growing from the first and last letters of "PROPHECY" (line 2), and grain stems and tassels growing from the first word of the heading ("A," line 1).

component.illusobjdesc: A nude, muscular male ascends through the sky. He has apparently broken free of the chains that still dangle from his wrists. His left arm is at his side; his right arm is bent back over his right shoulder. His right leg is bent behind him out of view. His hair may be curly. He faces forward with his head tilted up. This may be another representation of Orc or, more generally, humanity freed from its chains by revolution.
Chains dangle from the wrists of the ascending figure. Only one end of the chain is shown dangling from his raised arm, unlike other copies.
A bird flies on extended wings to the left and above the first letter of "PROPHECY" in the heading (line 2), and another bird flies within the upper loop of the first letter "P."
One rising bird with a forked tail flies on extended wings to the right of the descender of the final letter of "PROPHECY."

The first diagonal of "A" in line 1 grows at its lower end into a vine terminated by either grain stems with tassels or leaves. Descending from the middle of the letter is an intertwined vine. The second diagonal of "A" in line 1 grows at its lower end into arching grain stems with tassels.
The first letter of "PROPHECY" in line 2 grows into a loop that forms arching grain stems with tassels. Two vines are intertwined with the letter.
The second letter of "PROPHECY" in line 2 grows A shoot of a vine with ivy-like leaves or perhaps small flowers.
The third letter of "PROPHECY" in line 3 grows into a spiral vine.
The top of "H" in "PROPHECY" (line 3) grows into a vine with two loops. The vine terminates either in some leaves or two small flowers with prominent stamen.

The top of the last letter of "PROPHECY" in line 3 terminates in a flower with a prominent stamen and the descender grows into a vine running horizontally below the word. The vine has four loops, suggesting a spiral.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Between lines 7 and 8 of the text, a hovering nude male, perhaps an apocalyptic angel of the last trumpet, blows into a large trumpet he holds with at least his left hand. We see him from behind; his hair is long and streams to the left, as though blown by a wind. Issuing from the mouth of the trumpet is a great blast of fire. The fire expands toward a standing nude male holding a pole, perhaps unfurling a flag that terminates in a loop. Below, and evidently part of the same design, are further flames and smoke, including streams of fire or smoke between lines 14 and 16 of the text. In the lower left corner of the plate is a nude family group fleeing from the fires above and behind them. The male (father?) is in the middle; he holds the hand of a young boy on the left. He strides forward with his left leg and looks back at the flames. His hair may be curly. The woman (mother?) strides forward with her right leg, also turns back to the flames, and raises her left arm over her head. The fingers of her left hand are spread apart. The boy on the left strides forward with his left leg, also seems to be looking back, and raises his right arm over his head. All three figures stride over a small mound of earth or hill.

component.illusobjdesc: Between lines 8 and 9 of the text, a hovering male figure, perhaps an apocalyptic angel of the last trump, holds with both hands and blows into a large trumpet. He is nude. We see him from behind; his hair is long and streams to the left, as though blown by a wind. Issuing from the mouth of the trumpet is a great blast of fire that turns upward in the left margin of the plate. A wavy line extends from the darkened area around the angel's waist.

In the lower left corner of the plate is a nude family group fleeing from the fires above and behind them. The male (father?) is in the middle; he holds the hand of a young boy on the left. He strides forward with his left leg and looks back at the flames. His hair may be curly. The woman (mother?) strides forward with her right leg, also turns back to the flames, and raises her left arm over her head. The fingers of her left hand are spread apart. The boy on the left strides forward with his left leg, also seems to be looking back, and raises his right arm over his head. All three figures stride over a small mound of earth or hill.

In the center of the family group, a nude male, perhaps a father, strides forward with his left leg. He looks back at the flames behind him from which he is fleeing; his hair is curly. He holds the hand of the young boy on the left and may hold the hand of the woman on the right.

On the left of the family group is a nude male child. He strides forward with his left leg, fleeing the flames above and behind him. His head is turned back or to the left; his right arm is raised over his head. He holds the hand of the central male figure with his left hand.

On the right of the family group is a nude woman, perhaps the mother. She strides forward with her right leg, fleeing the flames above and behind her. Her head is turned back and to the left; her left arm is raised vertically, with the fingers of her left hand spread apart. Her hair may be drawn into a bun. She may hold the hand of the central male figure with her right hand.

Flames issue from the trumpet blown by the figure between lines 7 and 8 of the text. Similar tongues of fire or smoke extend toward the family group in the lower left corner of the plate and between lines 14 and 16 of the text.
The family group in the lower left corner of the plate runs over a mound of earth or low hill.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The top of the "h" in "The" ends in a diagonal line to the right, which then descends in a jagged line. A line with a loop extends from the letter "d" of the second word ("Guardian") in line 4. This may represent a vine. Several letters have vine-like extensions, some with loops (e.g., left of lines 5 and 19).

component.illusobjdesc: The top of the "h" in "The" ends in a diagonal line to the right, which then descends in a jagged line. A line with a loop extends from the letter "d" of the second word ("Guardian") in line 4. This may represent a vine. Several letters have vine-like extensions, some with loops (e.g., left of lines 5 and 19).

lg.l: The Guardian Prince of Albion burns in his nightly tent:
Sullen fires across the Atlantic glow to America's shore,
Piercing the souls of warlike men, who rise in silent night,
Washington, Hancock, Paine & Warren, Gates, Franklin & Green;
Meet on the coast glowing with blood from Albions fiery Prince.
Washington spoke; Friends of America, look over the Atlantic sea;
A bended bow in heaven is lifted, & a heavy iron chain
Descends link by link from Albions cliffs across the sea to bind
Brothers & sons of America, till our faces pale and yellow:
Heads deprest, voices weak, eyes downcast, hands work bruised,
Feet bleeding on the sultry sands, & the furrows of the whip
Descend to generations that in future times forget------
sea:
The strong voice ceas'd for a terrible blast swept over the heaving
The eastern cloud rent, on his cliffs stood Albions fiery Prince.
A dragon form clashing his scales at midnight he arose,
And flam'd fierce meteors round the land of Albion beneath;
His voice, his locks, his awful shoulders: & his glowing eyes

desc.objtitle: , Object 7 (Bentley b, Erdman b, Keynes b)

objnote.p: This plate is a variant of Plate 6 printed from a different copperplate than the one bearing Plate 6. This variant plate does not appear in any copy of *America*. Object 6 (Plate a) is printed on the recto of this impression of Plate b. The pencil shading lower left may have been added by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains considerable text, it would appear that the pictorial image is treated as a full-plate design. Centered just below line 2 is a winged dragon of a type traditionally called a wyvern. The creature is apparently flying through the air. It faces to the left, with a coiled or spiral tail with two loops on the right. Its skin looks scaly and its face is somewhat dog-like, with a partly opened mouth and large teeth. The top of its head bears a crest. Its front paws look almost like human hands. Below and to the left of its left paw is a jagged line, perhaps representing a bolt of lightning. Further to the left, and descending into the left margin, is an old man. His gown forms a long, snake-like tail behind him, rather like the wyvern's tail. He has a long beard and long hair. His right arm is at his side, but we can see that, with his right hand, he grasps a large book or tablet. His left arm reaches downward and he holds in his left hand a scepter or spear with a point. This figure may be Albion's Angel or Urizen (twice referred to in the text) with his book of laws. Below this descending figure is another jagged line, perhaps representing lightning, and several cloud outlines extending to the right margin above and below the last eight lines of text. Below these billowing clouds, in the plate's lower margin, is a landscape that includes a male figure. He is nude and squats or kneels on the ground, with his upper body bent forward. Both arms are raised and bent at the elbows; he grasps his head with both hands. This gesture expresses despair or terror. To the right of the figure is a fallen tree with a limb extending into the right margin.

component.illusobjdesc: Just below line 2 is a winged dragon of a type traditionally called a wyvern. The creature is apparently flying through the air. It faces to the left, with a snake-like coiled or spiral tail with two loops on the right. In this copy, a small like extends from the tail's end.Its skin looks scaly and its face is somewhat dog-like, with a partly opened mouth and large teeth. The top of the head bears a spiky crest. Its front paws look almost like human hands.

An old man descends head-first in the left margin. His gown forms a long, snake-like tail behind him. He has a long beard and long hair. His right arm is at his side, but we can see that, with his right hand, he grasps a large book or tablet. His left arm reaches downward and he holds in his left hand a scepter or spear with a point. This figure may be Albion's Angel or Urizen (twice referred to in the text) with his book of laws.

The male figure is nude and squats or kneels on the ground, with his upper body bent slightly forward and his face turned partly downward. Both arms are raised and bent at the elbows; he grasps his head with both hands. This gesture expresses despair or terror.
A jagged line below and to the left of the dragon's left paw may represent lightning.
A jagged line below the descending old man may represent lightning.
The lower half of the sky is filled with the outlines of clouds.
The trunk of a fallen tree appears in the landscape, lower right. One short branch and two roots are pictured.

lg.l: Reveal the dragon thro' the human; coursing swift as fire
To the close hall of counsel, where his Angel form renews.
In a sweet vale shelter'd with cedars, that eternal stretch
Their unmov'd branches, stood the hall; built when the moon
shot forth,
In that dread night when Urizen call'd the stars round his feet;
Then burst the center from its orb, and found a place beneath;
And Earth conglob'd, in narrow room, roll'd round its sulphur Sun.
To this deep valley situated by the flowing Thames;
Where George the third holds council. & his Lords & Commons meet;
Shut out from mortal sight the Angel came; the vale was dark
With clouds of smoke from the Atlantic, that in volumes roll'd
Between the mountains, dismal visions mope around the
house
On chairs of iron, canopied with mystic ornaments,
Of life by magic power condens'd; infernal forms art-bound
The council sat; all rose before the aged apparition;
His snowy beard that streams like lambent flames down his
wide breast
Wetting with tears, & his white garments cast a wintry light.
Then as arm'd clouds arise terrific round the northern drum;
The world is silent at the flapping of the folding banners;
So still terrors rent the house: as when the solemn globe
Launch'd to the unknown shore, while Sotha held the north-
-ern helm,
Till to that void it came & fell; so the dark house was rent,
The valley mov'd beneath; its shining pillars split in twain,
And its roofs crack across down falling on th'Angelic seats.
This is page 6 of America

desc.objtitle: , Object 8 (Bentley c, Erdman c, Keynes c)

objnote.p: This plate does not appear in any copy of *America*. It may have been intended to be placed between Plates 10 and 11 (Objects 12 and 13), or possibly following Plate b (Object 7). This impression bears Object 15 (Bentley Plate 15) on its verso. The pencil annotations were written by Blake. A vertical line drawn at the center of the plate may suggest that lines 18-49 are to be canceled.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The plate is primarily text, but is decorated with clouds and four figures. The uppermost figure, probably male, lies on a cloud with his torso turned to the left, and his head buried in his arms. The second figure -- another nude man -- flies head-first towards the ground. He blows into a large trumpet pointed at a nude man and a nude woman below. In the plate's lower left corner, the two figures appear to be engaged in a sexual act. The woman faces forward, with her arms lifted and her fingers spread wide. Her posture suggests surrender or ecstasy. She appears to be standing in front of a stony surface, perhaps the "mountains & cliffs of snow" mentioned in the text. The man, seen from behind, stands in front of her. His physique is muscular and his legs are positioned powerfully and comfortably apart; he may either be embracing or restraining the woman. At their feet appears to be the rocky surface of the ground. The positioning of the text and the interlinear illustrations suggests clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male figure hovers to the left of the text. With legs and arms extended, the figure flies downward and to the right.

A nude and muscular male figure sits on a cloud to the left of the text. He leans to the left, with his head buried in his arms; he appears to have curly hair. His right leg is bent at the knee and his left leg is stretched outward.

A male trumpeter flies hovers with his trumpet pointing towards the ground; his right leg is bent at the knee and his left leg is extended. His trumpet is aimed towards the couple embracing on the ground below.

A female figure faces forward; her arms are raised and fingers are stretched wide in a posture of ecstasy or surrender. Her head leans backward as she looks upward, with long hair streaming over her right shoulder. A nude man faces her, and appears to be support or restrain her; they appear to be engaged in a sexual act.
A nude male figure, seen from behind with legs spread wide, faces a female figure; he appears to support or restrain her. They appear to be engaged in a sexual act.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The spaces between lines of text contain human figures and vegetative motifs, including vines. Some bear leaves, most prominently between lines 13 and 15 and 25 and 27 of the printed text. The “T” in "Then" in line 1 grows into a vine with three loops; at the base of the letter stands an ambiguous figure, possibly a woman wearing a dress, who faces left. A small nude figure hovers to the left of the text. With legs and arms extended, the figure flies downward and to the right toward the letter “H” in "He" in line 3 of the printed text. Two birds fly above “Albions Angel rose” and another two birds fly to the left of “His” in line 4 of the printed text. Small birds fly to the left of line 4, above line 15, and to the right of lines 21-24 of the printed text.The upper torso of a figure, who appears to be an old, bearded man, is shown with arms extended to the right of line 6 of the printed text. He resembles the figure on Plate 12 in this copy. A small figure with legs outspread grasps a vine to the right of "pillar" in line 14 of the printed text. To the right of line 26 of the printed text, a female, possibly gowned, figure flies to the left. Two additional figures may sit on a vine to the right.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure, possibly a woman wearing a dress, stands at the base of the "T" in "Then" in line 1. She faces left and raises her arm 45 degrees.

A nude figure of indeterminate gender hovers to the left of the text. With legs and arms extended, the figure flies downward and to the right toward the letter “H” in "He" in line 3 of the printed text.

To the right of line 6 of the printed text (under the word "stood" in line 5), the upper torso of a figure appears with arms extended horizontally. It may be an old, bearded man. He appears to float next to a cloud. To his right, three diagonal marks may indicate flames. It may illustrate the lines "King breathing/with flames:" (lines 5-6 of the printed text).
To the right of "pillar" in line 14 of the printed text, a small nude figure faces left and raises its arms to hold a vine. Its legs are spread and extended. It may be floating.

To the right of line 26 of the printed text, a female figure who may be in a gown flies to the left. Her arm is raised horizontally. To her right, two figures rest on a cloud. One sits facing left and one reclines.

The spaces between lines of text and in the margins are filled with vegetative motifs. Some of these vines bear leaves, such as the large vines to the right of lines 14 and 26 of the printed text. A vine growing from the first letter of the first word in line 1 ("Then") includes three spiral loops; a vine form the word "of" in line 1 also has three spiral loops. The first word in line 5 of the printed text ("By") grows into a sheaf of wheat; the first word of line 13 of the printed text ("Smote") grows into a vine with leaves.

Several birds appear between the lines and in the margins of the text. One large illustration at the end of line 1 may be a bird; another large bird flies with wings outspread below line 15 of the printed text. Groups of smaller birds fly above "Albions" and "rose" (line 1), to the left of "His" (line 4 of the printed text), and to the right of line 21–23 of the printed text.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although containing a good deal of text, the plate is treated as a full-page design, with pictorial motifs filling the lower third of the plate and continuing up the left margin. In the lower margin, a muscular nude youth with curly, flame- like hair seems to be rising out of the ground. The figure's right knee and foot are prominent; his hands are placed on the ground and his arms, bent sharply at the elbows, seem to be pushing him upward. He looks up and to the right. This is probably Orc. To the left are a good many roots, as though we could see below the surface of the earth. Above these roots is a large plant growing up the left margin. It bears two large leaves and a long branch that terminates in a grain tassel. To the left of the main trunk or stem is a vine-like branch that spirals upward with one loop around the main stem. There are a few small plants and tufts of grass right of the nude male and left and right of the large plant.

component.illusobjdesc: A muscular nude youth with curly, flame-like hair seems to be rising out of the ground. His right knee and foot are prominent; his hands are placed on the ground and his arms, bent sharply at the elbows, seem to be pushing him upward. He looks up and to the right. This is probably Orc.
The figure appears to be rising from a small depression (possibly a grave?) in a mound of earth, small hill, or side of a cliff.

The surface of the earth is indicated to the right of the bottom figure by a few small plants with leaves and perhaps grass, far right. A few small plants or tufts of grass grow left and right of the main plant on the left.

A large plant dominates the left margin of the plate. We see its roots beneath the surface of the earth, two large leaves, and a long branch growing up the left margin that terminates in a grain tassel. A spiral vine also grows up the left margin, with one loop around the main stem.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The spaces between lines of text and in the margins are filled with vegetative motifs. Some of these vines bear leaves; large vines left of lines 2-5 and 7-15 include loops. On top of the second of these vines, just above the first word in line 7, is a small seated figure (poorly printed in this copy), bending forward and facing to the right with at least one leg extended to the right and one arm possibly reaching toward the foot. Another small figure seems to be hovering above "have" in the same line of text, facing left, one arm raised horizontally and one raised vertically, and legs spread apart. This figure may be holding the vine to the left. A vine growing from the first letter of the last word in line 7 ("go") includes two loops suggestive of a spiral. A bird with extended wings flies at the end of line 14; smaller birds fly above "will" (line 7) and "me" (line 9). The last word line 17 grows into a vine with two leaves; most of this vine turns to the left and underlines the last line of text.

A bird with extended wings flies at the end of line 15. Smaller birds fly above "will" (line 7) and "me" (line 9).
The last word of the final line of text grows into a vine with two leaves; most of this vine turns to the left and underlines the last line of text.

lg.l: Silent as despairing love, and strong as jealousy.
The hairy shoulders rend the links, free are the wrists of fire;
Round the terrific loins he siez'd the panting struggling womb;
It joy'd: she put aside her clouds & smiled her first-born smile;
As when a black cloud shews its light'nings to the silent deep.
Soon as she saw the terrible boy then burst the virgin cry.
I know thee, I have found thee, & I will not let thee go;
Thou art the image of God who dwells in darkness of Africa;
And thou art fall'n to give me life in regions of dark death.
On my American plains I feel the struggling afflictions
Endur'd by roots that writhe their arms into the nether deep:
I see a serpent in Canada, who courts me to his love;
In Mexico an Eagle, and a Lion in Peru;
I see a Whale in the South-sea, drinking my soul away.
O what limb rending pains I feel, thy fire & my frost
Mingle in howling pains, in furrows by thy lightnings rent;
This is eternal death; and this the torment long foretold.

objnote.p: This is a posthumous impression printed by Fredrick Tatham c. 1832.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains a good deal of text, Blake treated the pictorial image as a full-plate design. Above, an old, bearded, and gowned man sits among clouds. His long hair cascades over his left shoulder. He faces forward, but looks slightly to the left. His arms are raised horizontally; his hands seem to be holding the clouds on which they rest, palms down. His right leg is drawn up toward his chest in a contracted posture; the right knee and foot are prominent. His left leg is not pictured. The lines below his right foot may be a fold of his garment, but possibly a sandal. This figure is very probably Urizen. At the bottom of the plate is a dark and stormy sea with waves. The text panel is shaped in such a way as to suggest a cloud between the upper and lower parts of the design, or possibly a break between clouds. The design, particularly the figure, offers a contrasting parallel to the design on Plate 14 in this copy.

component.illusobjdesc: An old, bearded, and gowned man sits among clouds. His long hair cascades over his left shoulder. He faces forward, but looks slightly to the left. His arms are raised horizontally; his hands seem to be holding the clouds on which they rest, palms down. The visible fingers on his hands are spread apart. His right leg is drawn up toward his chest in a contracted posture; the right knee and foot are prominent. His left leg is not pictured. The lines below his right foot may be a fold of his garment, but possibly a sandal. This is probably Urizen.
Below the text is a dark and stormy sea with waves.
Dense clouds form both the surface on which the figure sits and his background. The text panel is shaped like a cloud, or possibly a break between clouds.
A jagged line below "like silver" in line 17 suggests a bolt of lightning over the sea.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Vine-like extensions spring from the first letter in line 1 (the "T" in "the"), the "O" of "Orc" (line 1), and the first letters in lines 9 and 12. All but the first include loops.

component.illusobjdesc: Vine-like extensions spring from the first letter in line 1, the "O" of "Orc," also in line 1. The latter includes one loop.
Vine-like extensions spring from the first letters in lines 9 and 12. Both include a loop.

lg.l: The terror answerd: I am Orc, wreath'd round the accursed tree:
The times are ended; shadows pass the morning gins to break: The colon is printed faintly in this copy.
The fiery joy, that Urizen perverted to ten commands,
What night he led the starry hosts thro' the wide wilderness;
That stony law I stamp to dust: and scatter religion abroad
To the four winds as a torn book, & none shall gather the leaves;
But they shall rot on desart sands, & consume in bottomless deeps;
To make the desarts blossom, & the deeps shrink to their fountains,
And to renew the fiery joy, and burst the stony roof.
That pale religious letchery, seeking Virginity,
May find it in a harlot, and in coarse-clad honesty
The undefil'd tho' ravish'd in her cradle night and morn:
For every thing that lives is holy, life delights in life;
Because the soul of sweet delight can never be defil'd.
Fires inwrap the earthly globe, yet man is not consumd;
Amidst the lustful fires he walks: his feet become like brass,
His knees and thighs like silver, & his breast and head like gold.The period is printed faintly in this copy.

objnote.p: This impression of Plate 11 is in the second of two states, with additional white line work in the lower left margin and just above the bottom edge of the plate. The first state is found only in Copy L. Object 14 (Bentley Plate 12) is printed on the verso of this impression.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text, the dense white-line hatching represents grain stems and tassels arching dramatically to the left. Below one of the two arching clusters of grain is a nude infant or child, probably male, lying supine on the ground. His arms are at his side and his body is rigid; he may be dead. Right and left of the child are two plants with large leaves and vine-like tendrils. The plant on the right bears two flowers. Both plants have been identified as poppies. The white-line crosshatching extending up the left margin of the text might represent the clouds of an approaching storm, smoke, the sky, or simply the chaos of the material world.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude infant or child, probably male, lies supine on the ground below arching grain stems. His arms are at his side and his body is rigid; he may be dead.
Below the text, the dense white-line hatching represents grain stems and tassels. Two prominent clusters of stems arch dramatically to the left.
Right and left of the child are two plants with large leaves and vine-like tendrils. The plant on the right has loopy stems and bears two flowers. Both plants have been identified as poppies.
The white-line crosshatching extending up the left margin of the text might represent the clouds of an approaching storm, smoke, the sky, or simply the chaos of the material world.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several letters begin or terminate with vine-like forms. The most prominent is the first letter of the first word in line 1, the last letter of "round" in line 7, and the middle letter of the second "the" in line 8. The right margin of the text is filled with vines, a few bearing leaves.

component.illusobjdesc: The letter "S" at the beginning of line 1 begins and terminates with vine-like forms, including loops.
The final letter of "round," line 7 of the text, has a vine trailing from its top. A vine sprouts from the middle letter of "the," second word from the end of line 8.
The right margin of the text is filled with vines, a few bearing leaves. One is looped (between lines 23 and 24 of the text).

lg.l: Sound! sound! my loud war-trumpets & alarm my Thirteen Angels!
Loud howls the eternal Wolf! the eternal Lion lashes his tail!
America is darkned; and my punishing Demons terrified
Crouch howling before their caverns deep like skins dry'd in the wind,
They cannot smite the wheat, nor quench the fatness of the earth,
They cannot smite with sorrows, nor subdue the plow and spade,
They cannot wall the city, nor moat round the castle of princes.
They cannot bring the stubbed oak to overgrow the hills.
For terrible men stand on the shores, & in their robes I see
Children take shelter from the lightnings, there stands Washington
And Paine and Warren with their foreheads reard toward the east
But clouds obscure my aged sight. A vision from afar!
Sound! sound! my loud war-trumpets & alarm my thirteen Angels:
Ah vision from afar! Ah rebel form that rent the ancient

Heavens! Eternal Viper self-renew'd, rolling in cloudsBlake etched an exclamation mark after "Heavens", but in this impression the vertical stroke was not inked, except for a bottom and top edge, and prints mostly as a blind embossment.
I see thee in thick clouds and darkness on America's shore.
Writhing in pangs of abhorred birth; red flames the crest rebellious
And eyes of death; the harlot womb oft opened in vain
Heaves in enormous circles, now the times are return'd upon thee,
Devourer of thy parent, now thy unutterable torment renews.
Sound! sound! my loud war trumpets & alarm my thirteen Angels.
Ah terrible birth! a young one bursting! where is the weeping mouth?
And where the mothers milk? instead those ever-hissing jaws
And parched lips drop with fresh gore; now roll thou in the clouds
Thy mother lays her length outstretch'd upon the shore beneath.
Sound! sound! my loud war-trumpets & alarm my thirteen Angels!
Loud howls the eternal Wolf: the eternal Lion lashes his tail!

objnote.p: Object 13 (Bentley Plate 11) is printed on the recto of this impression.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains considerable text, the pictorial image is treated as a full-plate design. Below the text, a nude, muscular, youthful male rises among flames. His hair is curly and snake-like; his mouth is open. He faces forward, but looks slightly to the left. His left leg is bent at the knee, as though he were stepping up and rising; his right leg is covered by flames. The figure is very probably Orc, the spirit of revolution. His arms are raised horizontally, with his hands resting on the flames. The visible fingers of both hands are spread apart; both hands are poised as though the man was calling forth the flames that surround him. The flames (of hell?) and accompanying smoke extend up both margins to the top of the plate and appear in the spaces between the text, particularly between lines 4 and 5. The design offers a contrasting parallel to the design on Plate 12.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude, muscular, youthful male rises among flames. His hair is curly and snake-like; his mouth is open. He faces forward, but looks slightly to the left. His left leg is bent at the knee, as though he were stepping up and rising; his right leg is covered by flames. This figure is very probably Orc, the spirit of revolution. His arms are raised horizontally, with his hands resting on the flames. The visible fingers of both hands are spread apart; both hands are poised as though the man was calling forth the flames that emanate from below.

The figure is surrounded by flames (of hell?) and possibly some smoke. The fires climb to the top of the plate along both margins and appear between lines 4 and 5 of the text and between lines 10 and 11 on the right. The gray washes over text areas also suggest smoke.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Vines appear at the end of lines 6 and 8 of the text. The higher vine includes three loops. Extensions of letters at the beginning of lines 3 and 10 form vine-like tendrils. The extension of the "y" in the first word of line 10 forms a loop. A loopy vine extends from the second letter of "those" (line 5); the extensions of the first letter of "Golden" (line 7) are also vine-like.

component.illusobjdesc: Extensions of letters at the beginning of lines 3 and 10 form vine-like tendrils. The extension of the "y" in the first word of line 10 forms a loop. A loopy vine extends from the second letter of "those" in line 5.
Vines appear at the end of lines 7 and to the right of line 8 of the text. The higher vine includes three loops.

lg.l: Thus wept the Angel voice & as he wept the terrible blasts
Of trumpets, blew a loud alarm across the Atlantic deep.
No trumpets answer; no reply of clarions or of fifes,
Silent the Colonies remain and refuse the loud alarm.
On those vast shady hills between America & Albions shore;
Now barr'd out by the Atlantic sea: call'd Atlantean hills;
Because from their bright summits you may pass to the Golden world
An ancient palace, archetype of mighty Emperies,
Rears its immortal pinnacles, built in the forest of God
By Ariston the king of beauty for his stolen bride,
Here on their magic seats the thirteen Angels sat perturb'd,
For clouds from the Atlantic hover o'er the solemn roof,

objnote.p: This impression of Plate 15 bears Object 8 (Bentley Plate c) on its recto.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains considerable text, the pictorial image is treated as a full-page design showing the surface and bottom of the sea. Above the text, the limp body of a nude female lies supine on a stony shore, with her legs on the right extending into the waves of the sea. Her head is bent back and her long hair descends below, as does her dangling right arm. She is probably dead, perhaps from drowning. Some spiky vegetation grows to the left of her head. A large bird, very probably an eagle, is perched on her right upper leg. The eagle's wings are extended and his curved beak hovers above the woman's abdomen. The bird may be eating (or about to eat) the corpse. The sky behind the bird is filled with clouds; both the sky and the sea on the right (perhaps the Atlantic, named several times in the text) are stormy. Below the text we see the dark waters of the deep and the bottom of the sea. Upon it lies supine a nude male, with his knees bent slightly and his left arm at his side. His body is emaciated and rigid; he is no doubt dead, probably from drowning. We can see his ribs; perhaps the sea creatures around him have been eating his flesh. These include one large fish and two small ones, all with their mouths open. A sea snake coils itself around the man's legs; another snake hovers above his chest. Five much smaller fish appear immediately below the text and in the right margin following the final two lines of text. Below the man, on the floor of the sea, are two further sea snakes or worms. Near the lower right corner is a large, spiral shell, probably a whelk (common to the Atlantic). There are two other, much smaller shells, one below the man's neck and one in the far lower right corner of the plate. Vegetation rises in the left margin of the text almost touching the female figure on the rocky shore. This vegetation may be seaweed. The twisted, loopy lines include, left of lines 5-8 of the text, a snake with an open mouth.

component.illusobjdesc: The limp body of a nude female lies supine on a rocky shore, with her legs on the right extending into the waves of the sea. Her head is bent back and her long hair descends below, as does her dangling right arm. Her right leg and right breast are prominent. She is probably dead, perhaps from drowning. The eagle perched on her body may be eating (or about to eat) her flesh.

A nude male lies supine on the floor of the sea. His knees are bent slightly and his left arm is at his side. His body is emaciated and rigid; he is no doubt dead, probably from drowning. We can see his ribs; perhaps because the sea creatures around him have been eating his flesh. A sea snake is entwined around and binds his legs.
A plant with spiky leaves grows left of the woman's head.

A large bird, very probably an eagle, is perched on the right upper leg of the nude female. The bird's body faces forward, but its head is turned to the left. We can see one of his talons on her leg. The eagle's wings are extended and his curved beak is poised above the woman's abdomen. The bird may be eating (or about to eat) the corpse.
Five small fish swim to the left just below line 18 and in the right margin following lines 17-18.

Two fish, one very large, swim to the right above the male corpse. A smaller fish swims to the left above the corpse's head. All three fish have their mouths open; the largest may have teeth. They may be feeding on the dead body.
A sea snake swims above the male corpse. The snake's mouth is slightly open. Its tail suggests a spiral.
A sea snake coils itself around the legs of the male corpse. The snake's mouth is slightly open.
Two sea snakes or worms appear on the floor of the sea beneath the human corpse.

The curving line left of lines 5-8 in the text is a snake with two loops in its body and facing to the right with mouth open. The snake's body is intertwined with the flag or vine extending from the first letter in line 8.

The spiral shell near the lower right corner of the plate may be from a whelk. However, the shell looks empty, and thus the whelk has died. There are two other, much smaller shells, one below the man's neck and one in the far lower right corner of the plate.
The upper surface of the waters below the text suggests waves.
Vegetation—probably seaweed—grows up the left margin of the text. These vine-line plants include at least two loops.
The upper body of the female corpse rests on the stony shore of the sea.
The sky is filled with stormy clouds.
The sea-perhaps the Atlantic (frequently named in the text)-is filled with storm-tossed waves.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text area contains several representational motifs, mostly vines. The first letter of the first word in line 2 sprouts into two vines, one with a flower or leaf at its termination (on the left) and one with two loops (on the right). The final letter of "England" in line 2 grows into a vine with one loop. On line 4 is a row of vines, some with leaves. Sitting on one such vine, just right of the word "cry" (line 4), is a small figure with legs spread, left arm raised horizontally, and right arm raised at 45 degrees (assuming that the figure is facing forward, which seems likely). Two large leaves complete this row of motifs; a worm or caterpillar rises above the leaf on the left. The first letter in line 7 extends into a looping vine. A vine extends from the last letter of "all," end of line 7. A bird flies at the end of line 5; another may be represented by the similar shape just above the right tip of the large leaf above the first bird. A vine, possibly with a leaf, extends from the first letter in line 15.

component.illusobjdesc: To the right of the word "cry" in line 5, a small figure sits on a vine with legs spread apart, left arm raised horizontally, and right arm raised at 45 degrees (assuming that the figure is facing forward, which seems likely).

The first letter in line 2 sprouts into two vines. The vine on the left terminates in a flower or leaf; the vine on the right forms two loops. The first letter in line 7 extends into a looping vine. The flag or vine extending from the first letter in line 8 is intertwined with the body of the snake in the margin.
The last letter of "England" in line 2 grows into a vine with a single loop.
The space around line 4 is filled with vine-like forms, some including leaves. Two large leaves end this group, close to the right margin of the plate.
The last word in line 7 of the text ("all") terminates in a vine extending horizontally to the right margin of the plate.
A worm or caterpillar rises above the leaf below "they" in line 3 of the text.
A vine, possibly with a leaf, extends from the first letter in line 15.

objnote.p: This is a posthumous impression printed by Frederick Tatham c. 1832.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains considerable text, the pictorial image is treated as a full-page design showing the surface and bottom of the sea. Above the text, the limp body of a nude female lies supine on a stony shore, with her legs on the right extending into the waves of the sea. Her head is bent back and her long hair descends below, as does her dangling right arm. She is probably dead, perhaps from drowning. Some spiky vegetation grows to the left of her head. A large bird, very probably an eagle, is perched on her right upper leg. The eagle's wings are extended and his curved beak hovers above the woman's abdomen. The bird may be eating (or about to eat) the corpse. The sky behind the bird is filled with clouds; both the sky and the sea on the right (perhaps the Atlantic, named several times in the text) are stormy. Below the text we see the dark waters of the deep and the bottom of the sea. Upon it lies supine a nude male, with his knees bent slightly and his left arm at his side. His body is emaciated and rigid; he is no doubt dead, probably from drowning. We can see his ribs; perhaps the sea creatures around him have been eating his flesh. These include one large fish and two small ones, all with their mouths open. A sea snake coils itself around the man's legs; another snake hovers above his chest. Five much smaller fish appear immediately below the text and in the right margin following the final two lines of text. Below the man, on the floor of the sea, are two further sea snakes or worms. Near the lower right corner is a large, spiral shell, probably a whelk (common to the Atlantic). There is one much smaller shell below the man's neck. In the far lower right corner is a minimally representational form that may be another shell. Vegetation rises in the left margin of the text almost touching thefemale figure on the rocky shore. This vegetation may be seaweed. The twisted, loopy lines include, left of lines 6-9 of the text, a snake with an open mouth.

objid.objcode: (recto of copperplate fragment of Bentley a,
recto of copperplate fragment of Erdman a,
recto of copperplate fragment of Keynes a)

objnote.p: This copperplate fragment was cut from left side of the copperplate of *America* Plate a (see Object 6 for an impression of Plate a). The back of this fragment was used by Thomas Butts, Jr., to etch and engrave his own work (see Object 18). Butts was a student of Blake's in the graphic arts beginning no later than 1806 and continuing until at least 1808. In our reproduction, right and left have been reversed to make the text more easily read.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This copperplate fragment includes portions of the title, main text, and illustrations to America, Bentley 5 (Erdman 3, Keynes 3). The bottom-most curves of the "ECY" in "PROPHECY" appear along the top edge of the plate. The descender of "Y" extends to the top left edge of the plate; one loop in the descender may be cut off. A bird with extended wings and a forked tale rises to the right of the descender. A portion of the horizontal body of a hovering figure appears in the bottom left of the plate. The figure's legs extend horizontally behind it; the left leg bends at the knee. It appears to be nude and seen from behind with its muscular calves, thighs, buttocks, and back bared. A serpentine line below the figure extends from its waist and ends to the right of its feet. Short, vertical lines above the figure's back form an indeterminate shape that resembles grass or grain tassels, and obscures portions of three lines of text.

component.illusobjdesc: The bottom-most curves of the "ECY" in "PROPHECY" appear along the top edge of the plate. The bottom loops of the "E" and "C" intertwine in a spiral. The long descender of "Y" suggests a vine. It extends to the top left edge of the plate, which appears to cut off one loop in the descender.
To the right of the descending line, a bird with extended wings and a forked tale flies upward.

A figure hovers in the bottom left of the plate; its head and arms are not included in the copperplate fragment. The figure's legs extend horizontally behind it and its left leg bends at the knee. It appears to be nude and seen from behind with its muscular calves, thighs, buttocks, and back bared.
A serpentine line extends across most of the lower half of the copperplate. It extends from the waist of the figure and ends to the right of its feet.
Short, vertical lines above the figure's back form an indeterminate shape that resembles grass or grain tassels, and obscures portions of three lines of text.

objid.objcode: (verso of copperplate fragment of Bentley a,
verso of copperplate fragment of Erdman a,
verso of copperplate fragment of Keynes a)

objnote.p: This copperplate is the back of a fragment cut from the left side of the copperplate of *America* Plate a (see Object 17 for the recto of this copperplate and Object 6 for an impression of Plate a). This verso of the copperplate was used by Thomas Butts, Jr., to etch and engrave his own work. Butts was a student of Blake's in the graphic arts beginning no later than 1806 and continuing until at least 1808. Butts may have copied the image from the work of another artist. Blake probably assisted Butts in the execution of this etching and engraving.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The face of an old, bearded man with curly hair complete fills the copperplate. His prominent hair and beard flow with flame-like curls, and his forelock curls fall over his forehead. He looks downward with furrowed brows. He may look at the cross, which may be wooden, in the lower right corner of the copperplate.
